column1: It is the capital of the co-extensive Dar es-Salaam Region
column2: which is one of Tanzania's 31 administrative regions and consists of five districts: Kinondoni in the north
column3: Ilala in the centre
column4: Ubungo and Temeke in the south and Kigamboni in the east across the Kurasini estuary.

column2: Mzizima (Swahili for "healthy town") was a coastal fishing village on the periphery of Indian Ocean trade routes. In 1865 or 1866
column3: Sultan Majid bin Said of Zanzibar began building a new city very close to Mzizima and named it Dar es Salaam. The name is commonly translated as "abode/home of peace"
column4: based on the Arabic dar ("house")
column5: and the Arabic es salaam ("of peace"). Dar es Salaam fell into decline after Majid's death in 1870
column6: but was revived in 1887 when the German East Africa Company established a station there. The town's growth was facilitated by its role as the administrative and commercial centre of German East Africa and industrial expansion resulting from the construction of the Central Railway Line in the early 1900s.

column1: German East Africa was captured by the British during World War I and became Tanganyika with Dar es Salaam remaining the administrative and commercial centre. Under British indirect rule

column4: Kariakoo and Ilala) areas developed at a distance from the city centre. The city's population also included a large number of workers from British India
column5: many of whom came to take advantage of the trade and commercial opportunities presented to them. After World War II
column6: Dar es Salaam experienced a period of rapid growth.

column2: including the formation and growth of the Tanganyika African National Union
column3: led to Tanganyika attaining independence from colonial rule in December 1961. Dar es Salaam continued to serve as its capital

column13: the Tanzanian government declared the Ujamaa policy
column14: which set Tanzania into a socialist path. The move slowed down the potential growth of the city as the government encouraged people not to move in cities but stay in Ujamaa socialist villages. However
column15: by the 1980s the Ujamaa policy proved to be a failure in combating increasing poverty and hunger that Tanzania faced
column16: and delayed the development that it needed. This led to the 1980s liberalization policy that virtually ended socialism and its proponents within Tanzania's government.

column9: the Dar es Salaam Stock Exchange expanded and the Dar es Salaam harbour continued to be the most important in Tanzania. The port is prominent for entrepot trade with landlocked countries such as Rwanda

column1: The region of Dar es Salaam is divided into five districts.
=== Districts of Dar es Salaam region ===
Dar es Salaam Region is divided into five administrative districts. All five are governed as municipal councils
column2: and so all of the city's suburbs or wards are affiliated with them. The regional commissioner is Aboubakar Kunenge.

column1: Kinondoni is the most populated amongst the districts

column4: also known as Coco Beach

column1: Due to close proximity to the equator and the warm Indian Ocean

column3: typified by hot and humid weather throughout much of the year. It has a tropical wet and dry climate (Köppen: Aw). Annual rainfall is approximately 1

column1: Dar es-Salaam is the most populous city in Tanzania. With a population increase of 5.6 percent per year from 2002 to 2012
column2: it is the third-fastest-growing city in Africa
column3: after Bamako and Lagos
column4: and the ninth-fastest-growing in the world. The metro population is expected to reach 15.12 million by 2020 and predicted to be as high as 76 million by the year 2100
column5: making it the third largest city in the world (after Lagos and Kinshasa).According to the 2012 national census

column10: with the exception of Oyster Bay

column12: severely taxing the transportation network. and raising the prospect of future urban overcrowding.

column1: Dar es Salaam is Tanzania's most important city for both business and government. The city contains high concentrations of trade and other services and manufacturing compared to other parts of Tanzania
column2: which has about 80 percent of its population in rural areas. Downtown includes  small businesses
column3: many of which are run by traders and proprietors whose families originated from the Middle East and the Indian sub-continent—areas of the world with which the settlements of the Tanzanian coast have had long-standing trading relations.

column4: The Bank of Tanzania
column5: the Dar es Salaam Stock Exchange and the city's important Magogoni fish market. Kisutu has businesses and offices and is the location of Dar es Salaam central railway station
column6: the PSPF Towers and the TPA tower.

column1: The government has been introducing a bus rapid transport or metro bus system under the Dar es Salaam bus rapid transit meaning 'mwendo kasi' in Kiswahili. The metro buses are managed by UDART a partnership company between UDA (Usafiri Dar es Salaam) and the government.
The bus rapid transit system Phase 1 is completed and already in operation by the Dar es Salaam Rapid Transit Agency
column2: a government-private sector entity
column3: and began operation on 10 May 2016. It is branded as UDA-RT (Usafiri Dar es Salaam Rapid Transit).  The first section runs between Kimara in the northwest to Kivukoni on the northern headland of the harbour. Phase 1 was funded by the World Bank
column4: African Development Bank and the Tanzanian government.

column1: The city has the country's busiest port: The port is located on the west of the Indian Ocean
column2: Kurasini creek south east of Dar es Salaam's central business District. The Port of Dar es Salaam handles 90% of the country's cargo.

column1: Due to huge influx of cargo and the slow pace of expansion a new cargo port 60 kilometres (37 miles) northwest of Dar es Salaam is proposed at Bagamoyo.
MV Kigamboni ferries run between south east of Kivukoni and north west of Kigamboni in Dar es Salaam.
Travel to urban and sub-urban parts of Dar es Salaam is provided by the Dar es Salaam commuter rail.
Tanzania Railways operates the Central Line from Dar es Salaam to Kigoma.

The city also hosts the head office of Tanzania Zambia Railways Authority (TAZARA) built in the late 1960s to early 1970s. The main terminal is located west of Dar es Salaam's central business district in north Yombo Vituka along Nelson Mandela road. The TAZARA Railway connects Dar es Salaam to Zambia.
Tanzania Standard Gauge Railway is a new railway station which is under construction. It will link the country to Rwanda and Uganda
column2: Burundi and Congo.

column1: The Julius Nyerere International Airport is the principal airport serving the country with three operating terminals; Terminal Three at Kipawa in Ilala Municipality. The airport is located west of Dar es Salaam's central business district.
Dar es-Salaam (and specifically the area of Oyster Bay) is home to the brightly coloured and tourist-oriented Tingatinga painting style. The Nyumba ya sanaa ("House of Art") is a cultural centre
column2: workshop and shop dedicated to Tanzanian art
column3: showcasing and promoting Tanzanian craftmanship. Prominent Tanzanian sculptor George Lilanga has donated some of his works to the centre
column4: including decorations of the building's main entrance.

column1: Dar es Salaam has two of the five museums comprising the National Museum of Tanzania consortium

column4: located in the outskirts of the city on the road to Bagamoyo

Dar es Salaam's first radio station began operation in the early 1950s "with little more equipment than a microphone and a blanket hung over a wall..." This project was overseen by Edward Twining.
Dar es Salaam is the educational centre of Tanzania. The city is home to several institutions of higher learning.
The University of Dar es Salaam is the oldest and second largest public university in Tanzania after the University of Dodoma. It is located in the western part of the city in north-east Ubungo

column1: The Ardhi University (ARU) was established on 1 July 1996 after transforming the former University College of Lands and Architectural Studies (UCLAS) which was then a Constituent College of the University of Dar es Salaam. Historically
column2: Ardhi University
column3: dates back to 1956 when it started as Surveying Training School offering land surveying technician certificate courses at the present location of Mgulani Salvation Army Camp in Dar es Salaam. In 1958
column4: the School was moved to the present location (i.e. the Observation Hill). In 1972
column5: the school was transformed to Ardhi Institute. Then the Institute offered two-year diploma programmes in the fields of Land Surveying and Land Management and Valuation. In the same year
column6: a three-year diploma program in Urban and Rural Planning was introduced. In 1975
column7: all the three-year diploma programmes were upgraded to Advanced Diplomas. The Building Design and Building Economics courses started in 1976 and 1978 respectively. In 1996 Ardhi Institute was affiliated with the University of Dar es Salaam as a constituent college of the university; subsequently its name changed to the University College of Lands and Architectural Studies (UCLAS). Within ten years
column8: UCLAS increased the number of academic programmes from six to 39. The programmes ranging from diplomas to PhDs were offered by two faculties
column9: the Faculty of Architecture and Planning (FAP) and the Faculty of Lands and Environmental Engineering (FLEE). As a result of these changes
column10: student enrollment increased from only 400 in 1996 to about 1
column12: the number of academic staff with PhD increased from 3 in 1996 to over 60 in 2012. At present there are over 80 PhD holders who have graduated from over 25 universities worldwide. In 2007 Ardhi University came into being following the signing of the Ardhi University Charter by His Excellency the President of The United Republic of Tanzania. Concurrently
column13: the structure and number of programmes and academic units has increased significantly. At present
column15: one institute and several centres. Schools include the School of Architecture
column16: Construction Economics and Management (SACEM); the School of Earth Sciences
column18: Business and Informatics (SERBI); the School of Environmental Science and Technology (SEST); and the School of Spatial Planning and Social Science (SSPSS)
column19: alongside the Institute of Human Settlements Studies (IHSS). The university offers undergraduate and postgraduate studies with postgraduate
column21: master's and PhD degrees in various disciplines.

column2: African footballer of the year 2015 for the domestic players

Tanzanian academic and author and one of Africa's experts on  constitutional law and development issues. He served as professor of law at the University of Dar es Salaam for many years and was the first to hold the Mwalimu Julius Nyerere Research Chair in Pan-African Studies at the university. He also taught at a number of universities around the world.
